column8: Saves time and effort in learning from others' experiences with various API's. It's especially helpful to learn about problems others' faced that might only be evident after consider time is spent experimenting with or using the API in production.
column9: I typically begin a search on Google and find myself navigating to Stack Overflow threads 90%+ of the time.
column10: Sometimes the opinions aren't sufficiently detailed to understand why the user has a positive or negative opinion.
column11: Detailed pros / cons analysis is helpful. Stack Overflow reputation of posting user is helpful too.
column16: a site that aggregated opinion data about API's used sentiment analysis algorithms could be useful
column17: aggregating the data could certainly help determine popularity of the API

column6: StackOverflow, various tool-specific email lists or Discourse forums. And Twitter!
column8: Generally, I am looking for answers to specific questions ("how do I solve problem X?"), rather than generalised opinions
column9: Google search, or browsing the "related questions" links on S.O.
column10: I'm sorry, this question is too vague to answer.
column11: I'm not sure what you mean by "provided opinion". S.O. actively discourages people from either giving answers that are just their personal opinions about the merits (or otherwise) of an approach, but instead to focus on curating specific answers to specific questions. So I judge the quality of an answer by the degree to which it (a) understands the problem, (b) provides a solution and (c) explains why the answer is appropriate (or how it works).
column15: This is another vague question that is hard to answer. It depends. In general, I look for a balance of power and complexity, whether the technology has good documentation, how mature it is, how widely adopted, etc. But ultimately: is it a good fit for the problem I want to solve?
column16: I'm not sure that I accept your characterisation that opinions and viewpoints are scattered across StackOverflow. That seems to misunderstand what S.O. does. In general, I think the only useful summarisation is just raw statistics, e.g. http://stateofjs.com/
column17: I don't know what you mean by 'support for the summarization of reviews', so it's hard to answer.

column8: Knowing issues with APIs before using them in a project is very helpful.
column9: I usually do a google search and go from there, this is most of the time superior to navigating the forum itself.
column10: It's hard to know what issues people have with APIs so it's difficult to come up with something to search for.  That's why I usually try something like "API XYZ issues" or "API XYZ problems" into google and see what comes up.
column11: I usually check if the poster is providing enough detail and if the question is specific to the API. Often questions seem to be about an API but eventually it turns out that the problem was something else and not the API at all. A broad question like "how do I X with API Y" usually indicates a low quality posting, where specific questions that show a specific issue when using a certain API are more helpful.
column15: Is the API mature, so it doesn't change every 10 days? Has it been used in production grade software before? Is the API constantly maintained? Are security issues addressed quickly? Is the API available in public repositories (e.g. Maven)? Is it easy to use?
column16: I'm not sure. You could divide it in like "highlights" and "pain points", maybe also give a score for matureness (e.g. how long as this thing be around), security (how many security issues did it have in the last few years, how fast were they fixed, etc.)
column17: It would help to quickly gather a list of possible API candidates for a project.
column18: Just relying on the summarization for deciding for or against an API will problably not be enough and may lead to decisions that are less than optimal.

column8: They might have already tried something and know pros and cons of certain library
column10: They provide many different opinions, and I have to aggregate all information and make my own decision
column15: Good documentation, many related blog posts and questions in internet, well-known products or websites use it
column16: Just go through everything and display in one place
column17: Improve the quality of software by providing valuable information, and the speed of development
column18: Wrong decision made because of lack of some information that can not be shared outside the company, some details

column8: Practical experience beats a sales pitch
column10: Different versions of an API - what might have worked once may no longer work now

column15: Good documentation, flexibility, an SDK doesn't hurt either
column17: Might take less time to reach the point where its possible to make a decision

column6: Stack Overflow, probably lots of others. I don't really keep track.
column8: If I don't know an API and I need to pick one, getting the opinion of a few others helps make the decision. If I need an answer, the insights of other developers can point me in the right direction.
column10: Not knowing if the developer has the opinion based on emotional experiences, or uninformed or incomplete facts, rather than based on an at least mostly complete knowledge of facts such as similar APIs, or other factors.
column11: The opinion stated, if the phrasing sounds like it comes from an experienced developer, if the phrasing sounds like it comes from a complete experience, etc.
column15: If the API is inspired or derives from a popular or well-designed other API, If the API feels intuitive and in-line with my past API experiences, if the API uses common and popular standards (REST, JSON, JSON API, etc), if the API has a well thought-out model layer/ERD, if the API is well-documented, if the community has a significant investment in the API, If the developers of the API are nice, involved in the community, invested in the project, and etc.

column8: Mainly the availability of too many alternatives. Reading others' opinions helps in narrowing down the options.
column9: Search, open a few results each in a different tab, read all of them.
column15: Documentation, error messages, speed, cost / licensing.
column16: It would probably be a manual job, akin to the various "awesome X" lists (awesome go, etc), but with more comments about the alternatives.
column17: It would save a lot of time.
column18: Reading about other users' experiences with APIs can help unearth small issues that may be very important when choosing a product.

column6: Stack Overflow, Apple Developer Forums, private Slack groups
column8: To benefit from other developers' learning, without having to waste time rediscovering solved problems.
column9: I use Google rather than using a forum's built-in search. I will post my own question if I can't find anything quickly.
column10: Finding answers to similar but distinct questions, because they muddy the search results. Also, finding wrong, unreliable, misinformed, or outdated answers.
column11: Cross-referencing other answers, comments on the post, alternate answers to the same question, testing, and checking against the documentation.
column15: Popularity (I don't want to be the first person to run into a problem), quality of code and documentation, non-triviality (could I just write it myself?).
column16: It's unclear what the question is asking. If you're asking what I do to summarize posts, e.g. to justify a decision to my coworkers, I'll say things like, "this post is more popular, but I don't like it because it goes against the documentation. This other post looks like a safer method."
column17: Finding popular, common, or (relatively) obvious answers quickly.
column18: Missing nuance. I'd say probably 10-20% of the time, I glean something from a relatively obscure comment on a post that proves to be the key to understanding something. I would worry that an automated summary might obscure these.
